awd_titl_txt: Linking Fundamental Structural and Physical Properties of the MAX Phases at Finite Temperatures through Synergetic Experimental and Computational Research
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Recently, a new class of nanolayered carbides and nitrides, commonly referred to as MAX phases, has attracted considerable attention as potential multi-functional/structural materials for harsh environments since they combine some of the best attributes of ceramics (high-temperature stability and strength) and metals (high thermal conductivity and resistance to fracture). MAX phases are an exciting, and technologically important class of high-temperature materials but much remains to be understood, especially about the influence of chemistry on their properties, and their transition from brittle to ductile behavior (at elevated temperatures). This project addresses this challenge by synergistically combining experiments and computer simulations. A better understanding of the relationship between chemistry and mechanical stability may enable the faster deployment of MAX phases in technologies that benefit from higher operating temperatures, making it possible to develop more reliable and efficient power generation (and propulsion) systems. In addition to contributions to the science and technology of MAX phases, the project supports activities related to curriculum development, K-12 outreach, high school teacher training, mentoring and contributing to the professional training and development of undergraduate and graduate student researchers.

TECHINCAL DETAILS: The overall goal of this project is to investigate the finite-temperature structural and thermo-mechanical properties of MAX phases (comprised of an early transition metal (M), an A-group element and X which is either carbon and/or nitrogen) and their solid solutions through high-throughput experimental and computational approaches. Computations are being used for the rapid screening of materials while high-throughput synthesis allows the fine exploration of alloying effects on the thermal, mechanical and structural properties of a wide range of MAX structures. The project's major scientific goal is to elucidate the microscopic mechanisms responsible for the ductile-to-brittle transition in these materials under the hypothesis that the anharmonic nature of the motion of the M and A layers in the structures drives the onset of mechanical instability. Conventional electronic structure calculations and ab initio molecular dynamics will be used to investigate the ground state and anharmonic properties of MAX phases while spark plasma sintering will be used for the high-throughput synthesis of compositional variants of MAX compounds pre-screened by computations. The project addresses fundamental questions related to the compositional stability of MAX phases, the effect of composition and structure on their finite-temperature mechanical properties as well as the microscopic basis for the brittle-to-ductile transition. Understanding of the influence of chemistry on thermo-mechanical stability of these materials will enable their faster deployment in important technologies.

por.por_cntn:
Broader Impact: The project has resulted in a deeper understanding of the connections between structure and thermo-mechanical properties of the novel high-temperature MAX phases. A framework has been put in place to facilitate the selection/design of better high-temperature MAX phases, through a quantitative integrated computational-experimental methodology. This generalized framework may be applied to the selection/design of other material classes with high dimensional complexity. The project also facilitated the integration of the research activities educational activities via the design of a new graduate course, Materials Design Studio, and the establishment of the new undergraduate program in materials science in the PI’s department;  participation in K-12 outreach activities by advising students and serving as judges in national and international science fairs;  participation in REU and LSAMP programs, fostering diversity enthusiasm for materials science at the undergraduate level by advising the Material Advantage chapter at Texas A&M, the Women in Materials Science (WIMS) organization and by organizing  the annual TAMU Summer School in computational materials science
Intellectual Merit: The stability, solubility, and finite-temperature structural and thermo-mechanical properties of a selected group of MAX phases and their solid solutions were investigated through combined experimental and computational approaches. A comprehensive experimental-computational framework to accelerate the discovery of novel MAX phases and their solid solutions has been established.  The research activities have enabled the elucidation of fundamental questions about the nature of the properties of MAX phases as well as the temperature and composition-dependence of their properties, particularly in the solid-solution space.
Through the synergistic interaction between experimental and computational materials science, the following major outcomes have been attained:* By carefully controlling the amount of aluminum and silicon that mix in Ti3(Al1−xSix)C2 MAX phases we first examined the effect of alloying on the mechanical properties of MAX phases and found that not only is there a noticeable improvement in the mechanical properties as well as the oxidation behavior in these alloys that result from the combination of stronger Ti3SiC2 carbide with the ability of Ti3AlC2 to form a protective aluminum oxide layer.* Another notable outcome of the present project was the computational investigation of hundreds of quaternary systems in which more than one metal M or metal A mixed in the M and A sublattices, respectively. This work, first of its kind, led to the identification of several systems capable of exhibiting a large degree of mixing. To date, Ge, Sb, Sn and Bi doping of the A site in Ti2AlC has been demonstrated and samples with wide ranges of composition have been synthesized and characterized.* Fundamental investigations of the intrinsic deformation mechanisms in MAX phases suggests that the strength of these systems is localized within the MX bonds, while the ability for these systems to deform extensively upon application of stress is due to the rather weak bonds between the M and A layers. Our theoretical work also showed that the stacking (Tin+1AlCn with different values of n) did not influence greatly the intrinsic resistance to shearing or cleaving in these systems.* Theoretical work in comparison with experiments led to the verification of out-of-plane ordering in quaternary MAX phases in which more than one M element is mixed in the M sublattice. We arrived at the conclusion that in some systems, ordering in which different M species occupy distinct M layers is the consequence of elastic interactions. This resolved the paradoxical observations of ordering in systems that had been calculated to be phase-separating.*Finally, through the combination of quantum mechanical calculations and advanced thermodynamic analysis, we were able to develop a framework that enabled the prediction of the sensitivity of synthesis experiments with specific phase composition targets to uncertainties not only in models used to predict the outcome of synthesis reactions but also uncertainties in the initial stoichiometries of the reactants. Results of this project are disseminated in a book chapter, 13 peer-reviewed journal papers, 2 doctoral theses, more than two dozen conference presentations and multiple national and international invited lectures. A number of graduate students, undergraduate students, and international exchange student received training in computational and experimental techniques.
